{{flag|India}} }} {{Burmese characters}} {{History of Burma}} The '''Konbaung dynasty''' ({{lang-my|ကုန်းဘောင်ခေတ်}}, {{IPA-my|kóʊɴbàʊɴ kʰɪʔ|pron}}), formerly known as the '''Alompra dynasty''', or '''Alaungpaya dynasty''', was the last dynasty that ruled [[Myanmar|Burma]]/[[Myanmar]] from 1752 to 1885. It created the second-largest empire in [[history of Myanmar|Burmese history]] and continued the administrative reforms begun by the [[Toungoo dynasty]], laying the foundations of the modern state of Burma. The reforms, however, proved insufficient to stem the advance of the [[British Empire|British]], who defeated the Burmese in all three [[Anglo-Burmese wars]] over a six-decade span (1824–1885) and ended the millennium-old Burmese monarchy in 1885. An expansionist dynasty, the Konbaung kings waged campaigns against [[Manipur]], [[Rakhine State|Arakan]], [[Ahom kingdom|Assam]], the [[Mon (ethnic group)|Mon]] kingdom of [[Pegu]] and the [[Thai people|Siamese]] kingdom of [[Ayutthaya Kingdom|Ayutthaya]], thus establishing the {{nowrap|'''Third Burmese Empire'''}}. Subject to later wars and treaties with the British, the modern state of [[Burma]] can trace its current borders to these events. Throughout the Konbaung dynasty, the [[Capital city|capital]] was relocated several times for religious, political and strategic reasons. ==History== ===Establishment=== The dynasty was heroically founded by a village chief, who later became known as [[Alaungpaya]], in 1752 to challenge the [[Restored Hanthawaddy Kingdom]] which had just toppled the [[Taungoo dynasty]]. By 1759, Alaungpaya's forces had reunited all of Burma (and [[Manipur]]) and driven out the [[French colonial empire|French]] and the British who had provided arms to Hanthawaddy.{{sfn|Phayre|1883|p=153}} [[File:Lion throne, Amarapura Palace.jpg|thumb|left|Lion Throne in the throne hall of the royal palace of Amarapura (Painting by Colesworthy Grant, 1855.]] Alaungpaya's second son, [[Hsinbyushin]], came to the throne after a short reign by his elder brother, [[Naungdawgyi]] (1760–1763). He continued his father's expansionist policy and finally took Ayutthaya in 1767, after seven years of fighting. ===Reforms=== Realising the need to modernise, the Konbaung rulers tried to enact various reforms with limited success. King [[Mindon Min|Mindon]] with his able brother Crown Prince [[Kanaung Mintha|Kanaung]] established state-owned factories to produce modern [[weapon]]ry and [[good (accounting)|goods]]; in the end, these factories proved more costly than effective in staving off foreign invasion and conquest. Mindon also tried to reduce the tax burden by lowering the heavy [[income tax]] and created a [[property tax]], as well as [[duties]] on foreign exports. These policies had the reverse effect of increasing the tax burden, as the local elites used the opportunity to enact new taxes without lowering the old ones; they were able to do so as control from the centre was weak. In addition, the duties on foreign exports stifled the burgeoning trade and commerce. Konbaung kings extended administrative reforms begun in the Restored Toungoo dynasty period (1599–1752), and achieved unprecedented levels of internal control and external expansion. They tightened control in the lowlands and reduced the hereditary privileges of [[Shan people|Shan]] [[saopha|chiefs]]. They also instituted commercial reforms that increased government income and rendered it more predictable. Money economy continued to gain ground. In 1857, the crown inaugurated a full-fledged system of cash taxes and salaries, assisted by the country's first standardised silver coinage.{{sfn|Lieberman|1996|p=184-187}} Nonetheless, the extent and pace of reforms were uneven and ultimately proved insufficient to stem the advance of British colonialism.{{sfn|Myint-U|2001}} ===Relations with Siam=== In 1760, Burma began a series of wars with [[Ayutthaya Kingdom|Siam]] that would last well into the middle of the 19th century. By 1770, Alaungpaya's heirs had [[Burmese–Siamese War (1765–67)|temporarily defeated Siam (1767)]], subdued much of [[Laos]] (1765) and defeated [[Sino–Burmese War (1765–1769)|four invasions]] by [[Qing China]] (1765–1769).{{sfn|Lieberman|2003|p=184–187}} With the Burmese preoccupied for another two decades by another impending invasion by the Chinese,{{sfn|Dai|2004|p=145–189}} the Siamese recovered their territories by 1770, and went on to [[Burmese–Siamese War (1775–76)|capture Lan Na by 1776]].{{sfn|Wyatt|2003|p=125}} Burma and Siam went to war until [[Burmese–Siamese War (1849–1855)|1855]] but after decades of war, the two countries exchanged Tenasserim (to Burma) and Lan Na (to Siam). ===Relations with China=== In the defence of its realm, the dynasty fought four wars successfully against the Qing dynasty of China which saw the threat of the expansion of Burmese power in the East. In 1770, despite his victory over the Chinese armies, King Hsinbyushin sued for peace with China and concluded a treaty to maintain bilateral trade with the Middle Kingdom which was very important for the dynasty at that time. The Qing dynasty then opened up its markets and restored trading with Burma in 1788 after reconciliation. Thenceforth peaceful and friendly relations prevailed between China and Burma for a long time. ===Relations with the British and downfall=== Faced with a powerful China and a resurgent Siam in the east, [[Bodawpaya]] acquired western kingdoms of [[Rakhine State|Arakan]] (1784), [[Manipur]] (1814) and [[Ahom kingdom|Assam]] (1817), leading to a long ill-defined border with [[British India]].{{sfn|Myint-U|2006|p=109}} [[European ethnic groups|Europeans]] began to set up trading posts in the [[Irrawaddy delta]] region during this period. Konbaung tried to maintain its independence by balancing between the [[French colonial empire|French]] and the [[British Empire|British]]. In the end it failed, the British severed diplomatic relations in 1811, and the dynasty fought and lost three wars against the [[British Empire]], culminating in total annexation of Burma by the British. [[File:Scene upon the terrace of the Great Dagon Pagoda at Rangoon.jpg|thumb|The [[Shwedagon Pagoda]] during the [[First Anglo-Burmese War]] (1824–26)]] The British decisively defeated the Burmese in the [[First Anglo-Burmese War]] (1824–1826). Burma was forced to cede Arakan, Manipur, Assam and [[Tanintharyi Region|Tenasserim]], and pay a large indemnity of one million [[pounds sterling|pounds]]. In 1837, King [[Bagyidaw]]'s brother, [[Tharrawaddy Min|Tharrawaddy]], seized the throne, put Bagyidaw under house arrest and executed the chief queen [[Me Nu]] and her brother.{{sfn|Buyers}} Tharrawaddy made no attempt to improve relations with Britain. [[File:Thibaw Min 1885 crop.jpg|thumb|The last king, Thibaw Min (right), here with Queen Supayalat and her sister Princess Supayagyi, was forcibly deposed in a war with the British colonialists in 1885.]] His son [[Pagan Min|Pagan]], who became king in 1846, executed thousands – some sources say as many as 6,000 – of his wealthier and more influential subjects on trumped-up charges.{{cite web|url= http://www.san.beck.org/20-8-BurmaMalaya1800-1950.html#a1|title=Burma, Malaya and Siam 1800–1950|author=Sanderson Beck|accessdate=22 April 2007}} During his reign, relations with the British became increasingly strained. In 1852, the [[Second Anglo-Burmese War]] broke out. Pagan was succeeded by his younger brother, the progressive [[Mindon Min|Mindon]]. Mindon attempted to bring Burma into greater contact with the outside world, and hosted the [[Fifth Buddhist council|Fifth Great Buddhist Synod]] in 1872 at [[Mandalay]], gaining the respect of the British and the admiration of his own people. Mindon avoided annexation in 1875 by ceding the [[Karenni States]]. He died before he could name a successor, and [[Thibaw Min|Thibaw]], a lesser prince, was manoeuvred onto the throne by Hsinbyumashin, one of Mindon's queens, together with her daughter, [[Supayalat]]. ([[Rudyard Kipling]] mentions her as Thibaw's queen, and borrows her name, in his poem "[[Mandalay (poem)|Mandalay]]") The new [[Thibaw Min|King Thibaw]] proceeded, under Supayalat's direction, to massacre all likely contenders to the throne. This massacre was conducted by the queen.{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} [[File:Saya Chone's "Abdication of King Thibaw".png|thumb|A traditional painting by Saya Chone depicts the abdication of King Thibaw.]] The dynasty came to an end in 1885 with the forced abdication and exile of the king and the royal family to [[India]]. The British, alarmed by the consolidation of [[French Indochina]], annexed the remainder of the country in the [[Third Anglo-Burmese War]] in 1885. The annexation was announced in the British parliament as a New Year gift to [[Queen Victoria]] on 1 January 1886. Although the dynasty had conquered vast tracts of territory, its direct power was limited to its capital and the fertile plains of the [[Irrawaddy valley]]. The Konbaung rulers enacted harsh levies and had a difficult time fighting internal rebellions. At various times, the [[Shan people|Shan]] states paid tribute to the Konbaung Dynasty, but unlike the Mon lands, were never directly controlled by the Burmese. ==Government== The Konbaung dynasty was an [[absolute monarchy]]. As in the rest of Southeast Asia, the traditional concept of kingship aspired to the ''[[Chakravartin]]'' (Universal Monarchs) creating their own ''[[Mandala (Southeast Asian political model)|mandala]]'' or field of power within the ''[[Jambudvipa|Jambudipa]]'' universe, along with the possession of the white elephant which allowed them to assume the title ''Hsinbyushin'' or ''Hsinbyumyashin'' (Lord of the White Elephants), played a significant role in their endeavours. Of more earthly importance was the historical threat of periodic raids and aiding of internal rebellions as well as invasion and imposition of overlordship from the neighbouring kingdoms of the Mon, Tai Shans and Manipuris.{{sfn|Surakiat|2006|p=8, 11, 25}} ===Administrative divisions=== The kingdom was divided into provinces called ''myo'' ({{my|ၿမိဳ႕}}).{{sfn|Bird|1897|p=104}}{{sfn|Seekins|2006|p=51}} These provinces were administered by ''Myosa'' ({{my|ၿမိဳ႕စား}}), who were members of the royal family or the highest-ranking officials of the Hluttaw.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=153}} They collected revenue for the royal government, payable to the Shwedaik (Royal Treasury) in fixed instalments and retained whatever was left over.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=153}} Each ''myo'' was subdivided into districts called ''taik'' ({{my|တိုက်}}), which contained collections of villages called ''ywa'' ({{my|ရွာ}}).{{sfn|Bird|1897|p=104}} The kingdom's peripheral coastal provinces ([[Pegu]], [[Tenasserim Division|Tenasserim]], [[Mottama|Martaban]] and [[Rakhine State|Arakan]]) were administered by a Viceroy called a ''Myowun'', who was appointed by the king and possessed civil, judicial, fiscal and military powers.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=153}} Provincial councils (''myoyon'') consisted of ''myo saye'' (town scribes), ''nakhandaw'' (receivers of royal orders), ''sitke'' (chiefs of war), ''htaunghmu'' (jailer), ''ayatgaung'' (head of the quarter), and ''dagahmu'' (warden of the gates).{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=154}} Each province was divided into districts called ''myo'', each led by a ''myo ok'' (if appointed), or by a ''myo thugyi'' (if the office was hereditary).{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=154}} The Viceroy of Pegu was assisted by several additional officials, including an ''akhunwun'' (revenue officer), ''akaukwun'' (customs collector), and a ''yewun'' (conservator of port).{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=154-155}} The outlying tributary [[fiefdom]]s on the edges of the kingdom were autonomous in practice and nominally administered by the king.{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=77}} These included the [[Shan language|Tai-speaking]] (what became the [[Shan States]] during British rule), Palaung, [[Kachin State|Kachin]] and [[Manipur]]i kingdoms. The tributary princes of these fiefdoms regularly pledged allegiance and offered tribute to the Konbaung kings (through rituals called ''[[gadaw|gadaw pwedaw]]''){{sfn|Philips|1951|p=117, 121}} and were accorded with royal privileges and designated ''[[sawbwa]]'' (from Shan saopha, 'lord of the sky'){{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=77}}{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=102}} In particular, the families of Shan ''sawbwa''s regularly intermarried into Burmese aristocracy and had close contact with the Konbaung court.{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=77}} ===Royal agencies=== The government was centrally administered by several advisory royal agencies, following a pattern established during the [[Taungoo dynasty]].{{sfn|Seekins|2006|p=50}} The [[Hluttaw]] ({{my|လွှတ်တော်}}, lit. "place of royal release," c.f. Council of State){{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=152}} held legislative, ministerial and judicial functions, administering the royal government as delegated by the king.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=152}} Sessions at the Hluttaw were held for 6 hours daily, from 6 to 9 am, and from noon to 3 pm.{{sfn|Taw|1913|p=47}} Listed by rank, the Hluttaw was composed of: * Head of the Council - the king, his heir apparent, or a high-ranking prince who presided over the Hluttaw as its nominal head.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=156}} * ''Wunshindaw'' ({{my|ဝန်ရှင်တော်}}, Prime Minister) - served as the Chief Minister of the Hluttaw, an office established during the reign of [[Mindon Min]] and most notably served by the [[Kinwun Mingyi U Kaung]]{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=156}}{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=157-158}}{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=133}} * Four ''Wungyi'' ({{my|ဝန်ကြီး}}) - jointly administered the Hluttaw's administrative portfolio and shared joint responsibility for the kingdom's administration.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=152}}{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=65}} ** Four ''Wundauk'' ({{my|ဝန်ထောက်}}) - served as deputies to the ''Wungyi'' * ''Myinzugyi Wun'' ({{my|မြင်ဇူးကြီးဝန်}}, lit. "Minister of the Cavalry Regiments") - as the highest regular army position, oversaw the [[Tatmadaw]].{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=66}} * ''Athi Wun'' ({{my|အသည်ဝန်}}, lit. "Minister of the ''Athi''") - responsible for allocating [[corvée]] labour resources and mobilisation of taxpaying commoners, called ''athi'', during wartime{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=152}}{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=66}} The ''[[Byedaik]]'' ({{my|ဗြဲတိုက်}}, lit. "Bachelor Chambers," with ''Bye'' stemming from [[Mon language|Mon]] ''blai'' {{mnw|ဗ္ကဲာ}}, "bachelor") served as the [[Privy Council]] by handling the court's internal affairs and also served as an interlocutor between the king and other royal agencies.{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=66}} The Byedaik consisted of: * Eight ''Atwinwun'' ({{my|အတွင်းဝန်}}, c.f. 'Ministers of the Interior')- communicated business affairs of the Hluttaw to the king, administered internal transactions of general affairs relating to the royal court.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=159}} * ''Thandawzin'' ({{my|သံတော်ဆင့်}}, "Heralds") - performed secretarial duties and attended king's audiences to note king's orders and forward them to Hluttaw for inscription.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=160}} * ''Simihtunhmu'' ({{my|ဆီမီးထွန်းမှူး}}, lit. "Lamp Lighthers") - kept a list of all persons sleeping in the palace{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=160-161}} * ''Hteindeinyanhmu'' ({{my|ထိန်းသိမ်းရေးမှူး}}, "caretakers of royal appointments") - performed menial tasks such as maintaining the palace furniture, draperies and other appointments{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=161}} The ''Shwedaik'' ({{my|ရွှေတိုက်}}) was the Royal Treasury, and as such, served as the repository of the state's precious metals and treasures.{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=67}} Moreover, the Shwedaik retained the state's archives and maintained various records, including detailed genealogies of hereditary officials and census reports.{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=67}}{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=161}} The Shwedaik was composed of: * ''Shwedaik Wun'' ({{my|ရွှေတိုက်ဝန်}}) - [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]]{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=161}} * ''Shwedaik Saw'' ({{my|ရွှေတိုက်စော}}) - Governor of the Treasury{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=161}} * ''Shwedaik Kyat'' ({{my|ရွှေတိုက်ကြပ်}}) - Superintendent{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=161}} * ''Shwedaik Saye'' ({{my|ရွှေတိုက်စာရေး}}) - Clerk of the Treasury{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=161}} * ''Shwedaik Thawkaing'' ({{my|ရွှေတိုက်သော့ကိုင်}}) - Keeper of the Treasury Key{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=161}} ===Royal service=== [[File:Konbaung royal scribe.jpg|thumb|A royal scribe, 1855]] Each royal agency included a large retinue of middle and low level officials responsible for day-to-day affairs. These included the: * ''Nakhandaw'' ({{my|နားခံတော်}}) - charged with conveying communications to and from the King and Hluttaw.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=157}} Also served as intermediary between royal agencies and between king and ministers.{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=67}} Collected, sorted, interpreted reports, read proclamations at official gatherings, transmitted orders to provincial councils.{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=67}} * ''Sayedawgyi'' ({{my|စာရေးတော်ကြီး}}; great chief clerks) - performed executive level work and preliminary investigations for trials{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=157}} ** ''Saye'' ({{my|စာရေး}}; clerks) * ''Ameindawgyi'' ({{my|အမိန့်တော်ကြီး}}; writers of great orders) - prepared and issued royal orders after necessary preliminary steps had been taken.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=157}} * ''Athonsaye'' ({{my|အသုံးစာရေး}}; clerks of works) - oversaw construction and repairs of all public buildings{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=157}} * ''Ahmadawye'' ({{my|အမှတ်တော်ကြီး}}; recorders of orders) - drafted orders and letters to be issued by Hluttaw{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=157}} * ''Awayyauk'' ({{my|အဝေးရောက်}}; distant arrivals) - received and read letters coming from distance before submission to ministers{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=157}} * ''Thandawgan'' ({{my|သံတော်ခံ}}) - ceremonial officers who received letters on behalf of the king{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=158}} and 3 classes of ceremonial officers: # ''Letsaungsaye'' (clerks of presents) - read lists of offerings made to the King at royal functions{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=158}} # ''Yonzaw'' (master of ceremonies) - arranged royal functions and audiences of the King{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=158}} # ''Thissadawge'' (recorders of great oaths) - administered oaths of fealty to those entering the royal service{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=158}} ===Royal court=== [[File:Saya Chone's "Royal Audience".png|thumb|"Royal Audience," a traditional painting by Saya Chone]] Konbaung society was centred on the king, who took many wives and fathered numerous children, creating a huge extended royal family which formed the power base of the dynasty and competed over influence at the royal court. It also posed problems of succession at the same time often resulting in royal massacres. The ''Lawka Byuha Kyan'' ({{my|လောကဗျူဟာကျမ်း}}), also known as the ''Inyon Sadan'' ({{my|အင်းယုံစာတန်း}}), is the earliest extant work on Burmese court protocols and customs.{{sfn| Working People's Daily|1988}} The work was written by the Inyon Wungyi Thiri Uzana, also known as the Inyon Ywaza, during the reign of [[Alaungpaya]], the founder of the Konbaung dynasty.{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=70}} Royal court life in the Konbaung dynasty consisted of both codified rituals and ceremonies and those that were innovated with the progression of the dynasty. Many ceremonies were composed of Hindu ideas localised and adapted to existing traditions, both Burmese and Buddhist in origin. These rituals were also used to legitimise the rule of Burmese kings, as the Konbaung monarchs claimed descent from [[Maha Sammata]] through the [[Shakya|Sakyan clan]] (of which [[Gotama Buddha]] was a member). Life in the royal court was closely regulated. [[Eunuchs]] ({{my|မိန်းမဆိုး}}) oversaw the ladies of the royal household and apartments.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=205}} Inferior queens and concubines could not reside in the main palace buildings.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=205}} [[File:Bodleian Library MS. Burm. a. 6. Parabeik illustrating royal pastimes 03-04.jpg|thumbnail|right|The King and Queen observing a ceremony involving riders on horseback. From an 18th-century ''parabeik'' (picture book)]] Brahmins, generally known as ''ponna'' ({{my|ပုဏ္ဏား}}) in Burmese, served as specialists for ritual ceremonies, astrology, and devotional rites to Hindu deities at the Konbaung court.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=160-161}} They played an essential role in king-making rituals, consecration and ablution ceremonies called ''[[abhiseka]]'' ({{my|ဗိဿိတ်}}).{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=159}} Court Brahmins ({{my|ပုရောဟိတ်}}, ''parohita'') were well embedded in daily life at the court, advising and consulting the king on various matters.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=168}} A social hierarchy among the Brahmins determined their respective duties and functions.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=168}} Astrologer Brahmins called ''huya'' ({{my|ဟူးရား}}) were responsible for determining astrological calculations, such as determining the auspicious moment for the foundation of a new capital, a new palace, pagoda, or assumption of the royal residence, announcing an appointment, leaving a place, visiting a pagoda or starting a military campaign.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=169}} They also established the religious calendar, prepared the almanac ({{my|သင်္ကြန်စာ}}), calculated upcoming solar and lunar eclipses, identified major festival days based on the lunar cycle, and communicated auspicious times and dates.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=169}} A special group of Brahmins who performed ''abhiseka'' rituals were also selected as ''pyinnya shi'' ({{my|ပညာရှိ}}), appointed royal counselors.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=177}} ===Military=== {{expand section|date=November 2013}} ===Royal rituals=== Lavish affairs were also organised around the life ceremonies of royal family members.{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=57}} Brahmins presided over many of these auspicious ceremonies, including the construction of a new royal capital; consecration of the new palace, the royal ploughing ceremony; the naming, first rice feeding and cradling ceremonies; the ''abhiseka'' head anointing rituals, and the King's participation in [[Thingyan|Burmese New Year]] (Thingyan) celebrations.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=175}} During Thingyan, a group of 8 Brahmins sprinkled water blessed by a group of 8 Buddhist monks, throughout the palace grounds, at the [[Hluttaw]], various courts, the major city gates, and the 4 corners of the capital.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=175}} The king attended many of the ceremonies involving royal family members, from cradling ceremonies ({{my|ပုခက်မင်္ဂလာ}}) to ear-boring ceremonies, from marriages to funerals.{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=57}} Specific buildings in the royal palace served as the venue for various life ceremonies. For instance, the Great Audience Hall was where young princes underwent the ''[[shinbyu]]'' coming-of-age ceremony and were ordained as [[Pabbajja|monk novices]].{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=27}} This was also the venue where young princes ceremonially had their hair tied in a topknot ({{my|{{my|သျှောင်ထုံး}}}}).{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=27}} Elaborate Burmese New Year feasts took place at the Hmannandawgyi (Palace of Mirrors): on the third day of the New Year, the king and chief queen partook in Thingyan rice, cooked rice dipped in cold perfumed water, while seated on their throne.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=29}} Musical and dramatic performances and other feasts were also held in that complex.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=29}} ====Consecration ceremonies (''abhiseka'')==== [[File:Konbaung Dynasty Abhiseka.jpg|thumb|A nineteenth-century watercolor painting by royal painters depicts an Konbaung ''abhiseka'' ceremony. The king and queen are respectively seated in the pavilion, surrounded by a retinue of Brahmins.]] The most significant court functions of a king's reign were the ''[[abhiseka]]'' or consecratory rituals, held at various times throughout a king's reign, to reinforce his place as the patron of religion ([[Sasana]]) and righteousness.{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=57}} ''Abhiseka'' rituals all involved the pouring of water from a conch on the candidate's (usually the king's) head, instructing him what to do or not to do for the love of his people and warning him that if he failed to oblige, he might suffer certain miseries.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=175}} Ablution rituals were the responsibility of a group of 8 elite Brahmins uniquely qualified to perform the ritual.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=175}} They were to remain chaste before the ceremony.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=175}} Another group of Brahmins was responsible for the consecration of the Crown Prince.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=175}} There were 14 types of ''abhiseka'' ceremonies in total:{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=175}} # ''Rājabhiseka'' ({{my|ရာဇဘိသိက်}}) - coronation of the king # ''Muddhabhiseka'' ({{my|မုဒ္ဓဘိသိက်}}) - formal vow by the king to work for the propagation of the [[Sasana]] (Buddha's teachings); held five years after accession{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=136}}{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=175}} # ''Uparājabhiseka'' ({{my|ဥပရာဇဘိသေက}}) - installation of crown prince{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=136}} # ''Mahesībhiseka'' ({{my|မဟေသီဘိသေက}}) - coronation of chief queen{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=136}} # ''Maṅgalabhiseka'' ({{my|မင်္ဂလာဘိသေက}}) - held to celebrate the possession of [[White elephant (animal)|white elephants]]{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=136}} # ''Siriyabhiseka'' ({{my|သီရိယဘိသေက}}) - held to renew the king's glory, held on occasion{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=136}} # ''Āyudighabhiseka'' ({{my|အာယုဒီဃဘိသေက}}) - held to gain longevity, held on occasion{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=136}} # ''Jayabhiseka'' ({{my|ဇေယျာဘိသေက}}) - held to ensure victory and success in war{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=136}} # ''Mahābhiseka'' ({{my|မဟာဘိသေက}}) - held to increase economic prosperity, held seven years after accession{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=136}} # ''Sakalabhiseka'' ({{my|သကလာဘိသေက}}) - held to ensure peace in the kingdom{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=136}} # ''Vijayabhiseka'' ({{my|ဝိဇယဘိသေက}}) - held to conquer enemies{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=175}} # ''Mandabhiseka'' ({{my|Manda beittheit}}) - held to marry the candidate to a queen of royal lineage.{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=450}} # ''Singabhiseka'' ({{my|Thenga beittheit}}) - held to recommit a king to abide by the laws, whereupon full powers for the government and administration of the country are conferred{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=450}} ====Coronation==== ''Rajabhiseka'' ({{my|ရာဇဘိသိက်}}) - the Coronation of the king, which was presided over by Brahmins, was the most important ritual of the royal court.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=136}}{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=174}} The ceremony was typically held in the Burmese month of ''[[Kason]]'', but did not necessarily occur during the beginning of a reign.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=174}}{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=136}} The ''Sasanalinkaya'' states that [[Bodawphaya]], like his father, was crowned only after establishing control over the kingdom's administration and purifying the religious institutions.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=174}} The most important features of this ritual were: the fetching of the anointing water; the ceremonial bath; the anointment; and the king's oath.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=147}} Elaborate preparations were made precisely for this ceremony. Three ceremonial pavilions (''Sihasana'' or Lion Throne; ''Gajasana'' or Elephant Throne; and the ''Marasana'' or Peacock Throne) were constructed in a specifically designated plot of land (called the "peacock garden") for this occasion.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=137}} Offerings were also made to deities and Buddhist ''[[paritta]]''s were chanted.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=136}} Specially designated individuals, usually the daughters of dignitaries including merchants and Brahmins, were tasked with procuring anointing water midstream from a river.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=137-138}} The water was placed in the respective pavilions.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=138}} At an auspicious moment, the king was dressed in the costume of a [[Brahma]] and the queen in that of a queen from ''[[devaloka]]''.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=139}} The couple was escorted to the pavilions in procession, accompanied by a white horse or a white elephant.{{sfn|Harvey|1925|p=325}}{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=139}} The king first bathed his body in the Morasana pavilion, then his head in the Gajasana pavilion.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=140}} He then entered the Sihasana pavilion to assume his seat at the coronation throne, crafted to resemble a blooming [[lotus (genus)|lotus]] flower, made of [[figwood]] and applied gold leaf.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=140}} Brahmins handed him the five articles of coronation regalia ({{my|မင်းမြောက်တန်ဆာ}}, ''Min Myauk Taza''): # White umbrella ({{my|ထီးဖြူ}}, ''hti byu''){{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=204}} # Crown, in the form of a crested headdress ({{my|မကိုဋ်}}, ''magaik''){{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=204}} # Sceptre ({{my|သန်လျက်}}, ''thanlyet''){{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=204}} # Sandals ({{my|ခြေနင်း}}, ''che nin''){{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=204}} # [[Fly-whisk]], made of yak tail ({{my|သားမြီးယပ်}}, ''thamyi yat''){{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=204}} At his throne, eight princesses anointed the king by pouring specially procured water atop his head, each using a conch bedazzled with gems white solemnly adjuring him in formulae to rule justly.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=140}}{{sfn|Harvey|1925|p=325}} Brahmins then raised a [[white umbrella]] over the king's head.{{sfn|Harvey|1925|p=325}} This anointment was repeated by eight pure-blooded Brahmins and eight merchants.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=141}} Afterward, the king repeated words ascribed to Buddha at birth: "I am foremost in all the world! I am most excellent in all the world! I am peerless in all the world!" and made invocation by pouring water from a golden ewer.{{sfn|Harvey|1925|p=325}} The ritual ended with the king taking refuge in the [[Three Jewels]].{{sfn|Harvey|1925|p=325}} As part of the coronation, prisoners were released.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=141}} The king and his pageant returned to the Palace, and the ceremonial pavilions were dismantled and cast into the river.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=142}} Seven days after the ceremony, the king and members of the royal family made an inaugural procession, circling the city moat on a gilt state barge, amid festive music and spectators.{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=450}} ====Installation of the Crown Prince==== ''Uparājabhiseka'' ({{my|ဥပရာဇဘိသေက}}) - the Installation of the ''[[Uparaja]]'' (Crown Prince), in Burmese ''Einshe Min'' ({{my|အိမ်ရှေ့မင်း}}), was one of the most important rituals in the king's reign. The Installation Ceremony took place in the ''Byedaik'' (Privy Council).{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=129}} The Crown Prince was invested, received appenages and insignias, and was bestowed a multitude of gifts.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=129-135}} The king also formally appointed a retinue of household staff to oversee the Prince's public and private affairs.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=131-135}} Afterward, the Crown Prince was paraded to his new Palace, commiserate with his new rank.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=135}} Preparations for a royal wedding with a princess, specially groomed to become the new king's consort, then commenced.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=135}} ====Feeding of the first betel==== ''Kun U Khun Mingala'' ({{my|ကွမ်းဦးခွံ့မင်္ဂလာ}}) - the Feeding of the First Betel ceremony was held about 75 days after the birth of a prince or princess to bolster the newborn child's health, prosperity and beauty.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=105}} The ceremony involved the feeding of [[betel]], mixed with camphor and other ingredients. An appointed official ({{my|ဝန်}}) arranged the rituals preceding the ceremony.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=105}} These rituals included a specific set of offerings to the Buddha, indigenous spirits (''[[yokkaso]]'', ''[[akathaso]]'', ''[[bhummaso]]'', etc.), Guardians of the Sasana, and to the parents and grandparents of the child, all of which were arranged in the infant's chamber.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=106}} Additional offerings were made to the Hundred ''[[Phi]]'' ({{my|ပီတစ်ရာနတ်}}), a group of 100 Siamese spirits headed by [[Nandi (bull)|Nandi]] ({{my|နန္ဒီနတ်သမီး}}), personified by a Brahmin figure made of [[Desmostachya bipinnata|kusa grass]], which was ceremonially fed scoops of cooked rice with the left hand.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=106}}{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=108}} ====Naming ceremony==== ''[[Namakarana|Nāmakaraṇa]]'' ({{my|နာမကရဏ}}) – the naming ceremony took place 100 days after the birth of a prince or princess.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=106}} Food was also offered for the dignitaries and entertainers in attendance.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=107}} The infant's name was inscribed on a gold plate or on [[palm leaf]].{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=107}} The night before the ceremony, a ''[[pwe]]'' was held for the attendees.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=107}} The dawn of the ceremony, Buddhist monks delivered a sermon to the court.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=108}} Afterward, at the Chief Queen's apartment, the infant was seated on a divan with the Chief Queen, with respective attendees from the royal court seated according to rank.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=109}} A Minister of the Interior then presided over ceremonial offerings ({{my|ကုဗ္ဘီး}}) made to the [[Triple Gem]], the 11 ''[[Deva (Buddhism)|deva]]'' headed by [[Thagyamin]], 9 Hindu deities, indigenous ''[[nat (spirit)|nat]]'', and the 100 ''Phi''.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=106-7}}{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=109}} A protective prayer was then recited.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=110}} After the prayer, a ''pyinnyashi'' prepared and 'fed' Nandi. At the auspicious moment calculated by astrologers, the name of the infant was read out thrice by the royal herald.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=110}} Afterward, another royal herald recited an inventory of presents offered by the dignitaries in attendance.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=110}} At the closing of the ceremony, a feast ensued, with attendees fed in the order of precedence.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=110}} Offerings to the Buddha were shuttled to the pagodas, and those to Nandi, to the sacrificial Brahmins.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=110}} ====Royal Ploughing Ceremony==== {{Details|Royal Ploughing Ceremony}} [[File:Saya Chone's "Royal Ploughing Ceremony".png|thumb|A depiction of the Royal Ploughing Ceremony by Saya Chone, a painter at the royal court]] ''Lehtun Mingala'' ({{my|လယ်ထွန်မင်္ဂလာ}})Also known as ''Mingala Ledaw'' ({{my|လယ်တော်မင်္ဂလာ}}) or ''Ledwin Mingala''. - the Royal Ploughing Ceremony was an annual festival of breaking ground with ploughs in the royal fields east of the royal capital, to ensure sufficient rainfall for the year by propitiating the Moekhaung Nat, who was believed to control rain.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=205}}{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=257}} The ceremony was traditionally linked to an event in [[Gotama Buddha]]'s life. During [[Suddhodana|King Suddhodana]]'s royal ploughing of the fields, the infant Buddha rose to stand, sat cross-legged and began to meditate, underneath the shade of a [[Syzygium jambos|rose apple]] tree.{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=257-258}} The ceremony was held at the beginning of June, at the break of the southwest monsoon.{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=258}} For the ceremony, the king, clad in state robes (a ''[[paso]]'' with the peacock emblem (''daungyut'')), a long silk surcoat or tunic encrusted with jewels, a spire-like crown (''tharaphu''), and 24 strings of the ''[[salwe]]'' across his chest, and a gold plate or frontlet over his forehead) and his audience made a procession to the ''leya'' (royal fields).{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=259}} At the ''ledawgyi'', a specially designated plot of land, milk-white oxen were attached to royal ploughs covered with gold leaf, stood ready for ploughing by ministers, princes and the kings.{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=260}} The oxen were decorated with gold and crimson bands, reins bedecked with rubies and diamonds, and heavy gold tassels hung from the gilded horns.{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=260}} The king initiated the ploughing, and shared this duty among himself, ministers and the princes.{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=261}} After the ceremonial ploughing of the ''ledawgyi'' was complete, festivities sprung up throughout the royal capital.{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=261}} ====Head-washing ceremony==== At [[Thingyan]] and at the end of the [[Vassa|Buddhist lent]], the king's head was ceremonially washed with water from Gaungsay Gyun (lit. Head Washing Island) between Martaban and [[Mawlamyine|Moulmein]], near the mouth of the [[Salween River]].{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=206}} After the [[Second Anglo-Burmese War]] (which resulted in Gaungsay Gyun falling under British possession), purified water from [[Irrawaddy River]] was instead procured. This ceremony also preceded the earboring, headdressing, and marriage ceremonies of the royal family.{{sfn|Yi|1982|p=124}} ====Obeisance ceremony==== The [[Gadaw|Obeisance ceremony]] was a grand ceremony held at the Great Audience Hall thrice a year where tributary princes and courtiers laid tribute, paid homage to their benefactor, the Konbaung king, and swore their allegiance to the monarchy.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=205}} The ceremony was held 3 times a year: # ''Hnit Thit Gadaw'' ({{my|နှစ်သစ်ကန်တော့}}){{sfn|Scott|1900|94}} - Beginning of the [[Thingyan|Burmese New Year]] (April){{sfn|DAS|1963|p=27}} # ''Wa-win Gadaw'' ({{my|ဝါဝင်ကန်တော့}}){{sfn|Scott|1900|94}} - Beginning of the [[Vassa|Buddhist Lent]] (June or July) - required the attendance of princes, ministers and city officials{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=27}} # ''Wa-gyut Gadaw'' ({{my|ဝါကျွတ်ကန်တော့}}){{sfn|Scott|1900|94}} - [[Thadingyut|End of the Buddhist Lent]] (October) - required the attendance of provincial governors and tributary princes (''sawbwa''){{sfn|DAS|1963|p=27}} During this ceremony, the king was seated at the Lion Throne, along with the chief queen, to his right.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=27}} The Crown Prince was seated immediately before the throne in a cradle-like seat, followed by princes of the blood (min nyi min tha).{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=27}} Constituting the audience were courtiers and dignitaries from vassal states, who were seated according to rank, known in Burmese as ''Neya Nga Thwe'' ({{my|နေရာငါးသွယ်}}):{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=27}} # ''Taw Neya'' ({{my|တော်နေရာ}});{{sfn|MLC|1993}} # ''Du Neya'' ({{my|ဒူးနေရာ}});{{sfn|MLC|1993}} # ''Sani'' ({{my|စနည်း}});{{sfn|MLC|1993}} # ''Atwin Bawaw'' ({{my|အတွင်းဘဝေါ}});{{sfn|MLC|1993}} # ''Apyin Bawaw'' ({{my|အပြင်ဘဝေါ}}){{sfn|MLC|1993}} There, the audience paid obeisance to the monarch and renewed their allegiance to the monarch.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=27}} Women, barring the chief queen, were not permitted to be seen during these ceremonies.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=27}} Lesser queens, ministers' wives and other officials were seated in a room behind the throne: the queens were seated in the centre within the railing surrounding the flight of steps, while the wives of ministers and others sat in the space without.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=27}} ====Ancestor worship==== Throughout the Konbaung dynasty, the royal family performed [[ancestor worship|ancestral rites]] to honour their immediate ancestors. These rites were performed at the thrice a year at the Zetawunsaung ([[Jetavana]] Hall or "Hall of Victory"), which housed the Goose Throne ({{my|ဟင်္သာသနပလ္လင်}}), immediately preceding the Obeisance Ceremony.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=28}} On a platform in a room to the west of hall, the king and members of the royal family paid obeisance to images of monarchs and consorts of the Konbaung dynasty. Offerings and [[Pali]] prayers from a book of odes were also made to the images.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=28}} The images, which stood {{convert|6|to|24|in}} tall, were made of solid gold.{{sfn|Hall|1925|p=327-328}} Images were only made for Konbaung kings at their death (if he died on the throne) or for Konbaung queens (if she died while her consort was on throne), but not of a king who died after deposition or a queen who survived her husband.{{sfn|Hall|1925|p=327-328}} Items used by the deceased personage (e.g. sword, spear, betel box) were preserved along with the associated image.{{sfn|Hall|1925|p=327-328}} After the British conquest of [[Upper Burma]], 11 images fell into the hands of the Superintendent at the [[Raj Bhavan (West Bengal)|Governor's Residence, Bengal]], where they were melted down.{{sfn|Hall|1925|p=327-328}} ====Funerals==== {{see also|Konbaung tombs}} [[File:King Mindon's Tomb, Mandalay.jpg|thumb|The tomb of King Mindon on the grounds of [[Mandalay Palace]] in 1903]] When a king died, his royal white umbrella was broken and the great drum and gong at the palace's bell tower (at the eastern gate of the palace), was struck.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=204}} It was custom for members of the royal family, including the king, to be cremated: their ashes were put into a velvet bag and thrown into the river.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=23}} King [[Mindon Min]] was the first to break tradition; his remains were not cremated, but instead were buried intact, according to his wishes, at the place where his tomb now stands.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=23}} Before his burial, the King Mindon's body was laid in state before his throne at the Hmannandawgyi (Palace of Mirrors).{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=29}}{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=27}} ====Foundation sacrifice==== The Foundation Sacrifice was a Burmese practice whereby human victims known as ''myosade'' ({{my|မြို့စတေး}}) were ceremonially sacrificed by burial during the foundation of a royal capital, to propitiate and appease the [[Nat (spirit)|guardian spirits]]. to ensure impregnability of the capital city.{{sfn|Harvey|1925|p=321}} The victims were crushed to death underneath a massive teak post erected near each gateway, and at the four corners of the city walls, to render the city secure and impregnable.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=19}} Although this practice contradicted the fundamental tenets of Buddhism, it was in alignment with prevailing animistic beliefs, which dictated that the spirits of persons who suffered violent deaths became ''nat''s (spirits) and protective and possessive of their death sites.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=19}} The preferred sites for such executions were the city's corners and the gates, the most vulnerable defence points.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=19}} The Konbaung monarchs prescribed to ancient precedents and traditions to found the new royal city. Brahmins were tasked with planning these sacrificial ceremonies and determining the auspicious day according to astrological calculations and the signs of individuals best suited for sacrifice.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=19}} Usually, victims were selected from a spectrum of social classes, or unfortuitiously apprehended against will during the day of the sacrifice.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=19}} Women in the latter stages of pregnancy were preferred, as the sacrifice would yield two guardian spirits instead of one.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=19}} Such sacrifices took place at the foundation of Wunbe In Palace in [[Innwa|Ava]] in 1676 and may have taken place at the foundation of Mandalay in 1857.{{sfn|Harvey|1925|p=321}} Royal court officials at the time claimed that the tradition was dispensed altogether, with flowers and fruit offered in lieu of human victims.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=19}} [[Burmese chronicles]] and contemporary records only make mention of large jars of oil buried at the identified locations, which was, by tradition, to ascertain whether the spirits would continue to protect the city (i.e., so long as the oil remained intact, the spirits were serving their duty).{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=19}} Shwe Yoe's ''The Burman'' describes 52 men, women and children buried, with 3 buried under the post near each of the twelve gates of the city walls, one at each corner of those walls, one at each corner of the teak stockade, one under each of the four entrances to the Palace, and four under the Lion Throne.{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=482}} [[Taw Sein Ko]]'s ''Annual Report for 1902-03'' for the [[Archaeological Survey of India]] mentions only four victims buried at the corners of the city walls. ====Devotional rituals==== [[File:Four Guardian Kings in Burmese art.jpg|thumb|The Guardians of the Four Cardinal Directions (''[[Lokapala]]'') in Burmese depiction]] Brahmins at the Konbaung court regularly performed a variety of grand devotional rituals to indigenous spirits (''nat'') and Hindu deities.{{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=57}} The following were the most important devotional cults: * [[Ganesha]] (''Maha Peinne'' in Burmese) - During the Burmese month of [[Nadaw]] (November to December), a festival for Ganesha, the god of prudence and good policy, was held. Grain first reaped from the royal fields was sent to the [[Mahamuni Buddha Temple]] as an offering to Ganesha, in three huge containers in the shape of a buffalo, bullock and prawn, in which paddy, millet, and bulrush millet were respectively placed.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=34}} Ganesha, mounted on a peacock, was placed on a ceremonial procession and was then brought before the king, who after paying homage, scattered pieces of silver and clothes among the poor.{{sfn|DAS|1963|p=34}}{{sfn|Scott|1900|p=103}} Ganesha occupied a prominent place in royal ceremonies, especially as he was considered a guardian deity of the elephants.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=171}} Offerings to Ganesha, made in the Burmese month of [[Tazaungmon]] were established during Bodawpaya's reign.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=173}} * ''Phaya Ko Zu'' ({{my|ဘုရားကိုးဆူ}}, lit. "Nine Deities") - This was a devotional rite performmed by Khettara Brahmins. The deities referenced were either Buddhist: Buddha and the 8 [[arahat]]s, or non-Buddhist: 5 [[Hindu]] deities, including [[Chandi|Candi]] and Ganesha, and 4 ''nat''s).{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=170-171}} * [[Skanda (Buddhism)|Skanda]] ({{my|Sakanta or Sakanta Tattika}}) - King [[Bodawpaya]] reformed the annual ceremonial procession to honour Ganesha to instead honour Skanda, the god of war (and a son of [[Shiva]] and Candi), following the advice of a Brahmin from [[Benares]].{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=172}}Said Brahmin had the following issue: by the Govinda-maharajinda-aggamahadhammarajaguru. This procession was held in the Burmese month of [[Tabaung]].{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=173}} Skanda was closely linked with a deity called Citrabali-mara (Cittarapali-mar[a]), both of whom were connected to rituals mentioned in ''Rajamattan'', a standard reference for ceremonies at the royal court compiled during Bodawphaya's reign.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=173}} * Hindu deities: Candi (Canni), [[Indra]] ([[Thagyamin]]), [[Shiva]], [[Vishnu]], [[Asuras]] and the 4 [[Lokapala]] - These deities were placed at specific locations, at the entrances of the capital city, the royal palace, or in temples, to ward off evil.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=172}} * Other spirits (''nat''): Planets, Sky, Sun, Moon, ''Hon'' (the fire spirit){{sfn|Leider|2005|p=173}}{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=170}} ==Society and culture== [[File:Burmese Court Officials 1795.jpg|thumb|Burmese court officials in 1795]] ===Social classes=== During the Konbaung dynasty, Burmese society was highly stratified. Loosely modelled on the four [[Varna (Hinduism)|Hindu ''varna''s]], Konbaung society was divided into four general social classes ({{my|အမျိုးလေးပါး}}) by descent:{{sfn|MLC|1993}} # Rulers ({{my|မင်းမျိုး}}) or ''[[Kshatriya|Khattiya]]'' ({{my|ခတ္တိယ}}){{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=31}} # Ritualists ({{my|ပုဏ္ဏားမျိုး}}) or ''[[Brahmin|Brahmana]]'' ({{my|ဗြာဟ္မဏ}}){{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=31}} # Merchants ({{my|သူဌေးမျိုး}}) or ''[[Vaishya|Vessa]]'' ({{my|ဝေဿ}}){{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=31}} # Commoners ({{my|ဆင်းရဲသားမျိုး}}) or ''[[Shudra|Sudda]]'' ({{my|သုဒ္ဒ}}){{sfn|Myint-U|2001|p=31}} Society also distinguished between the free and slaves ({{my|ကျွန်မျိုး}}), who were indebted persons or [[prisoners of war]] (including those brought back from military campaigns in [[Kingdom of Arakan|Arakan]], [[Ayutthaya Kingdom|Ayuthaya]], and [[Manipur]]), but could belong to one of the four classes. There was also distinction between taxpayers and non-taxpayers. Tax-paying commoners were called ''athi'' ({{my|အသည်}}), whereas non-taxpaying individuals, usually affiliated to the royal court or under government service, were called ''ahmudan'' ({{my|အမှုထမ်း}}). Outside of hereditary positions, there were two primary paths to influence: joining the military ({{my|မင်းမှုထမ်း}}) and joining the [[Buddhist]] [[Sangha (Buddhism)|Sangha]] in the monasteries. ===Sumptuary laws=== [[Sumptuary law]]s called ''yazagaing'' dictated life and consumption for Burmese subjects in the Konbaung kingdom, everything from the style of one's house to clothing suitable to one’s social standing from regulations concerning funerary ceremonies and the coffin to be used to usage of various speech forms based on rank and social status.{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=411}}{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=406-407}}{{sfn|Andrus|1947|p=x}} In particular, sumptuary laws in the royal capital were exceedingly strict and the most elaborate in character.{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=406}} For instance, sumptuary laws forbade ordinary Burmese subjects to build houses of stone or brick and dictated the number of tiers on the ornamental spired roof (called ''[[pyatthat]]'') allowed above one’s residence— the royal palace's Great Audience Hall and the 4 main gates of the royal capital, as well as monasteries, were allowed 9 tiers while those of the most powerful tributary princes (''sawbwa'') were permitted 7, at most.{{sfn|Nisbet|1901|p=15}}{{sfn|Cocks|1919|p=161}} Sumptuary laws ordained 5 types of funerals and rites accorded to each: the king, royal family members, holders of ministerial offices, merchants and those who possessed titles, and peasants (who received no rites at death).{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=411-412}} Sumptuary regulations regarding dress and ornamentation were carefully observed. Designs with the [[peacock]] insignia were strictly reserved for the royal family and long-tailed hip-length jackets ({{my|ထိုင်မသိမ်းအင်္ကျီ}}) and surcoats were reserved for officials.{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=409}} [[Velvet]] sandals ({{my|ကတ္တီပါဖိနပ်}}) were worn exclusively by royals.{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=409-10}} [[Gold]] anklets were worn only by the royal children. {{sfn|Scott|1882|p=411}} [[Silk]] cloth, [[brocade]]d with gold and silver flowers and animal figures were only permitted to be worn by members of the royal family and ministers’ wives. {{sfn|Scott|1882|p=411}} Adornment with jewels and precious stones was similarly regulated. Usage of ''hinthapada'' ({{my|ဟင်္သပဒါး}}), a [[vermilion]] dye made from [[cinnabar]] was regulated.{{sfn|Scott|1882|p=411}} ===Demography=== [[File:Burmese equestrian sports.jpg|thumb|Konbaung era [[Myinkhin Thabin]]]] Throughout the Konbaung dynasty, cultural integration continued. For the first time in history, the [[Burmese language]] and culture came to predominate the entire [[Irrawaddy river|Irrawaddy valley]], with the [[Mon language]] and [[Mon people|ethnicity]] completely eclipsed by 1830. The nearer Shan principalities adopted more lowland norms. [[File:Manipuri horseman.jpg|thumb|An 1855 watercolour of a ''Kathe'' horseman from Manipur]] Captives from various military campaigns in their hundreds and thousands were brought back to the kingdom and resettled as hereditary servants to royalty and nobility or dedicated to [[pagodas]] and temples; these captives added new knowledge and skills to Burmese society and enriched Burmese culture. They were encouraged to marry into the host community thus enriching the [[gene pool]] as well.{{sfn|Symes|1800}} Captives from [[Manipur]] formed the cavalry called ''Kathè myindat'' (Cassay Horse) and also ''Kathè a hmyauk tat'' (Cassay Artillery) in the royal Burmese army. Even captured French soldiers, led by [[Chevalier Milard]], were forced into the Burmese army.{{sfn|Findlay|O'Rourke|2007|p=277}} The incorporated French troops with their guns and muskets played a key role in the later battles between the Burmese and the Mons. They became an elite corps, which was to play a role in the Burmese battles against the [[Thai people|Siamese]] (attacks and capture of [[Ayutthaya Kingdom|Ayutthaya]] from 1760 to 1765) and the [[Manchus]] (battles against the Chinese armies of the [[Qianlong Emperor]] from 1766 to 1769).{{sfn|Findlay|O'Rourke|2007|p=277}} [[Islam in Burma|Muslim]] eunuchs from [[Rakhine State|Arakan]] also served in the Konbaung court.{{sfn|Myint-U|2006|p=126}}{{sfn|Yegar|1972|p=10}}{{sfn|MHRJ|2007|p=57}}{{sfn|Fleischmann|1981|p=49}}{{sfn|Peletz|2007|p=73}} A small community of foreign scholars, missionaries and merchants also lived in Konbaung society. Besides [[mercenaries]] and adventurers who had offered their services since the arrival of the [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] in the 16th century, a few Europeans served as ladies-in-waiting to the last queen [[Supayalat]] in [[Mandalay]], a missionary established a school attended by [[Mindon Min|Mindon's]] several sons including the last king [[Thibaw Min|Thibaw]], and an [[Armenians|Armenian]] had served as a king's minister at [[Amarapura]]. Among the most visible non-[[Burmans]] of the royal court were Brahmins. They typically originated from one of four locales: * [[Manipur]] - acquired with the conquest of Manipur; perhaps from Bengal, since Manipur was Hinduised by Bengali Brahmins in the 1700s{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=178}} * [[Rakhine State|Arakan]] - acquired with the conquest of Arakan in 1785 by King [[Bodawpaya]]'s son, [[Thado Minsaw]]{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=178}} * [[Sagaing]] - long-established lines of Brahmins at Burman and Mon royal courts, who traced their origins to 9th century [[Sri Ksetra]] or 14th century Sagaing{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=178}} * [[Benares]] - Indian Brahmins from Benares who arrived in upper Burma between the late 1700s to early 1800s.{{sfn|Leider|2005|p=182}} ===Literature and arts=== {{Expand section|date=October 2013}} The evolution and growth of [[Burmese literature]] and theatre continued, aided by an extremely high adult male [[literacy rate]] for the era (half of all males and 5% of females).{{sfn|Lieberman|2003|p=202–206}} Foreign observers such as [[Michael Symes (diplomat)|Michael Symes]] remarked on widespread literacy among commoners, from peasants to [[Waterman (occupation)|watermen]].{{sfn|Symes|1800}} The Siamese captives carried off from Ayutthaya as part of the [[Burmese–Siamese War (1765–67)]] went on to have an outsize influence on traditional Burmese theatre and dance. In 1789, a Burmese royal commission consisting of Princes and Ministers was charged with translating Siamese and Javanese dramas from Thai to Burmese. With the help of Siamese artists captured from Ayutthaya in 1767, the commission adapted two important epics from Thai to Burmese: the Siamese Ramayana and the Enao, the Siamese version of Javanese [[Panji (prince)|Panji]] tales into Burmese ''[[Yama Zatdaw|Yama Zattaw]]'' and ''Enaung Zattaw''.Brandon, p. 27 One classical Siamese dance, called ''Yodaya Aka'' (lit. Ayutthaya-style dance) is considered one of the most delicate of all traditional [[Burmese dance]]s. ===Architecture=== [[File:Mandalay-Palace-from-Watch-Tower.JPG|thumb|The [[Mandalay Palace|royal palace of Mandalay]]]] {{Expand section|date=October 2013}} ===Religion=== {{Expand section|date=October 2013}} Monastic and lay elites around the Konbaung kings, particularly from Bodawpaya's reign, also launched a major reformation of Burmese intellectual life and monastic organisation and practice known as the Sudhamma Reformation. It led to, amongst other things, Burma's first proper state histories.Charney 2006: 96–107 ==Rulers== {|class="wikitable" !No !Title !Literal meaning !Lineage !Reign !Notes |- |1 |[[Alaungpaya]] | Future Buddha-King | village chief | 1752–1760 | founder of the dynasty and the Third Burmese Empire, invaded Ayutthaya |- |2 |[[Naungdawgyi]] | Royal Elder Brother | son | 1760–1763 | invaded Ayutthaya with his father |- |3 |[[Hsinbyushin]] | Lord of the White Elephant | brother | 1763–1776 | invaded and sacked [[Ayutthaya Kingdom|Ayutthaya]], invaded [[Chiang Mai]] and [[Laos]], invaded [[Manipur]], successfully repulsed 4 [[Qing Dynasty|Chinese]] invasions |- |4 |[[Singu Min|Singu]] | King Singu | son | 1776–1781 | |- |5 |[[Phaungkaza Maung Maung|Phaungka]] | Younger Brother (Lord of Phaungka) | cousin (son of Naungdawgyi) | 1782 | the shortest reign in Burmese history of just over one week |- |6 |[[Bodawpaya]] | Royal Lord Grandfather | uncle (son of Alaungpaya) | 1782–1819 | invaded and annexed [[Rakhine State|Arakan]], invaded Ayutthaya |- |7 |[[Bagyidaw]] | Royal Elder Uncle | grandson | 1819–1837 | invaded Ayutthaya with his grandfather, invaded [[Assam]] and [[Manipur]], defeated in the [[First Anglo-Burmese War]] |- |8 | [[Tharrawaddy Min|Tharrawaddy]] | King Tharrawaddy | brother | 1837–1846 | fought in the First Anglo-Burmese War as Prince of Tharrawaddy |- |9 |[[Pagan Min|Pagan]] | King Pagan | son | 1846–1853 | overthrown by Mindon after his defeat in the [[Second Anglo-Burmese War]] |- |10 |[[Mindon Min|Mindon]] | King Mindon | half-brother | 1853–1878 | sued for peace with the British;
